docs.lead_paragraph: As President Obama approaches the end of his administration's opening chapter, his advisers have begun a backstage debate over Chapter 2, which will be fundamentally different in tone, aspiration and political complexity. For his first 15 months, Mr. Obama has pounded away at four domestic initiatives. All four - economic stimulus, health care, Wall Street regulations and energy policy - reflected priorities of important Democratic constituencies. The next phase, which Mr. Obama set in motion by appointing a bipartisan panel on reducing the nation's debt, will not.

headline.main: Reduction Is Theme Of President's Next Act

docs.abstract: Caucus column; Pres Obama sets next phase of his presidency in motion by appointing bipartisan panel on reducing nation's debt; some advisers favor bold steps to show fiscal discipline, as 2010 deficit tops $1 trillion; others remain wary of undercutting fragile recovery; Obama's economic team calculates that one way to reduce deficit to 3 percent of gross domestic product from 10 percent within decade is 5 percent value-added tax, which would generate enough revenue to permit reduction in corporate tax rates Republicans favor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week I gave a talk at the Levy Institute's 19th annual Hyman P. Minsky Conference, held at the Ford Foundation. The occasion forced me to clarify my thoughts about financial reform; so here's a version of what I said.

headline.main: Six Doctrines in Search of a Policy Regime

docs.lead_paragraph: A Neuroscientist Studies Meditation and Finds a Place to Meditate | Clifford Saron, 56, who does research at the Center for Mind and Brain at the University of California, Davis, directs a study on the impact of sustained meditation on behavior and brain function. In a valley in West Marin, he puts his theories into practice. Katherine Ellison reports.
